### The Lognormal Distribution

A lognormal distribution is a continuous probability distribution of a random variable whose logarithm is normally distributed. Thus, if the random variable X is log-normally distributed, then $Y = ln(X)$ has a normal distribution. 
<p>
Equivalently, if Y has a normal distribution, then the exponential function of Y, $X = \exp(Y)$, has a log-normal distribution. 

<p>
-----------------------------------------------
<h4>Probability Density Function</h4>
\[ f(x) = {\displaystyle {\frac {1}{x\sigma {\sqrt {2\pi }}}}\ \exp \left(-{\frac {\left(\ln x-\mu \right)^{2}}{2\sigma ^{2}}}\right)} \mbox{ for } x>0\]

<p>
-----------------------------------------------
<h4>Mean</h4>
$$ { E(X) = \exp \left(\mu +{\frac {\sigma ^{2}}{2}}\right)} $$
<h5>Variance:</h5>	$$ { \operatorname{Var}(X) = \left[\exp(\sigma ^{2})-1\right]\exp(2\mu +\sigma ^{2})} $$

<h5>Skewness:</h5>	$$ { \operatorname{Skewness}(X) = (\exp(\sigma ^{2})+2){\sqrt {\exp(\sigma ^{2})-1}}} $$


### Worked Examples

<h3>Worked Example 1</h3>

In a certain chemical plant, the concentration of pollutants (X-in parts per million) has
lognormal distribution with parameter $ \mu =3.2$ and $ \sigma =1$

<h5>Exercises</h5>

a. Write the pdf of $ X$
b. Compute the mean and variance of $ X$
c. Compute the probability that the concentration exceeds 8 parts per million
